name: Actinic Keratoses (Solar Keratoses) / Bowen’s disease
symptoms: Rough, dry, scaly patches on sun-exposed areas (face, ears, hands, scalp); May be pink, red, or flesh-colored with sandpaper texture; Can itch, burn, or feel tender to touch; Slowly grows and may crust or thicken over time; Risk of progressing to squamous cell carcinoma if untreated
solution: Daily broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30+) and sun avoidance; Wear protective clothing and hats outdoors; Dermatologist treatment options: cryotherapy, topical agents, or photodynamic therapy; Regular dermatology follow-up to monitor for malignant change

name: Basal Cell Carcinoma
symptoms: Shiny, pearly bump or pink growth on sun-exposed skin; May bleed, ulcerate, or form a sore that won't heal; Sometimes appears as a flat, scaly patch with rolled edges; Common on the face, nose, ears, neck; Slow growth but may invade nearby tissue if untreated
solution: Seek dermatologist for early removal (surgical excision or Mohs surgery); Alternative options: curettage, electrodessication, topical therapy for superficial lesions; Avoid sun exposure; use sunscreen and protective clothing; Regular skin checks to detect recurrence or new tumors

name: Benign Keratosis (Seborrheic Keratosis)
symptoms: Waxy, wart-like, 'stuck-on' growths often brown/black/tan; May appear on face, chest, back or shoulders; Surface can be rough, greasy, or crumbly; Usually asymptomatic but may itch if rubbed; Common in older adults and increases with age
solution: Generally benign — no treatment required; Remove if symptomatic or for cosmetic reasons (cryotherapy, curettage, laser); Avoid picking or scraping to prevent infection; See dermatologist if rapid change or bleeding occurs

name: Dermatofibroma
symptoms: Firm, small, raised nodule commonly on legs or arms; Often brown, pink, or reddish and feels hard to touch; May dimple inward when pinched (positive dimple sign); Usually painless but can itch or be tender; Benign and typically remains stable over time
solution: No treatment necessary unless symptomatic or for cosmesis; Excision is definitive if removal requested (may leave scar); Laser therapy may help pigmentation but not always removal; Monitor for changes and consult dermatologist if concerned

name: Melanoma
symptoms: Dark, irregular mole or lesion that changes size, shape, or color; Asymmetry, irregular borders, multiple colors (ABCDE: Asymmetry, Border, Color, Diameter, Evolution); May itch, bleed, or develop crusting; Can arise on any skin surface, including palms, soles, or under nails; Aggressive tumor — early detection critical
solution: Urgent dermatology or oncology referral for biopsy and staging; Surgical excision with clear margins; lymph node evaluation if indicated; Advanced disease may need immunotherapy, targeted therapy, or radiotherapy; Strict sun protection and regular follow-up with skin checks

name: Melanocytic Nevi (Common Moles)
symptoms: Small, round or oval spot with uniform color (tan to brown); Can be flat or slightly raised with smooth borders; Usually stable for many years and asymptomatic; May darken with sun exposure or hormonal changes; Many individuals have multiple benign nevi
solution: Routine monitoring for changes (ABCDE criteria); Seek dermatology evaluation if rapid growth, irregular border, or color change occurs; Removal (excision/shave) if suspicious or for cosmetic reasons; Use sunscreen and avoid tanning beds

name: Vascular Skin Lesion
symptoms: Red, purple, or blue spots or raised bumps caused by blood vessels; Includes cherry angiomas, spider veins, and hemangiomas; Usually painless and may blanch on pressure; Often increases in number with age; Can bleed if traumatized
solution: No treatment needed unless symptomatic or cosmetic concern; Laser therapy, electrocautery, or excision can remove lesions; Avoid trauma to lesion to prevent bleeding or infection; Consult dermatologist for rapidly growing or symptomatic lesions
